|Title=Knowing the main forms of dyskinesias

The term dyskinesias is most often used to describe choreic and/or dystonic movements. The term dyskinesia is usually reserved :

- or to abnormal involuntary movements induced by L-dopa in Parkinson's disease: peak-dose (or mid-dose) dyskinesias or biphasic dyskinesias (beginning or end of dose);

- or dyskinesias induced by antipsychotics, including acute dyskinesias (cervical dystonia, oculogyric seizures, trismus, more common in young subjects), late dyskinesias during prolonged treatment (oral-facial-masticatory dyskinesias causing problems with phonation, swallowing and poor dental condition) which are difficult to treat, and akathisia (incessant trampling).

See the CEN website: www.cen-neurologie.fr where videos are available

question.title: What is the term usually reserved for abnormal involuntary movements induced by L-dopa in Parkinson's disease?

option_a.title: Dyskinesias
option_a.description: A general term for abnormal involuntary movements

option_b.title: Dyskinesias induced by L-dopa
option_b.description: A specific type of dyskinesia related to L-dopa treatment

option_c.title: Dyskinesias induced by antipsychotics
option_c.description: A specific type of dyskinesia related to antipsychotic treatment

option_d.title: Abnormal involuntary movements
option_d.description: A broad term that encompasses various types of dyskinesias

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the correct option
